repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Adds a new entry to `v:event` `abort_close`, which allows an autocmd to choose to abort the closure of a window

I'm not really sure if this is a valid way for v:event to be used since it looks like most events use it for giving readonly info, except for `CmdlineLeave`'s `v:event.abort`? but that seems more like a special case... 

My use case for this is an autocmd that pre-quit checks if the alternate buffer is a terminal (i.e. after a `git commit` invokes `nvr --remote-wait`) and instead of closing the window swaps back to the terminal buffer. Which kind of mimics what would happen if you open neovim in the terminal emulator instead of using `--remote` 

<details>
<summary>example code</summary>

``` lua
local function buf_on_screen(in_bufnr)
	local windows = vim.fn.gettabinfo(vim.fn.tabpagenr())[1].windows
	for _, win_id in ipairs(windows) do
		local bufnr = vim.fn.getwininfo(win_id)[1].bufnr

		if in_bufnr == bufnr then
			return true
		end
	end
end

vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('QuitPre', {
	pattern = '*',
	callback = function ()
		-- (crude?) check if the last buffer was a terminal
		local term_bufnr = vim.fn.bufnr '#'
		if term_bufnr == -1 or vim.api.nvim_buf_get_option(term_bufnr, 'buftype') ~= 'terminal' then
			return
		end

		-- I only need one view of a terminal on screen
		if buf_on_screen(term_bufnr) then
			return
		end

		-- for some reason this doesn't work?
		-- vim.v.event.abort_close = true

		vim.cmd 'let v:event.abort_close = v:true'
		vim.api.nvim_set_current_buf(term_bufnr)
	end
})

-- this will undo the effect of the autocmd above :/

-- vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('QuitPre', {
-- 	pattern = '*',
-- 	callback = function ()
-- 		vim.cmd [[ let v:event.abort_close = v:false ]]
-- 	end
-- })

```

</details>

comment_data.body: fwiw, I suggested `v:event_cancel` because that helps with discoverability when using and searching for `v:event`. The "event" prefix is also consistent with `eventhandler()`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

   VV(VV_LUA,              "lua",              VAR_PARTIAL, VV_RO),
+  VV(VV_CANCEL_EVENT,     "cancel_event",     VAR_BOOL, 0),

   VV(VV__NULL_BLOB,       "_null_blob",       VAR_BLOB, VV_RO),
   VV(VV_LUA,              "lua",              VAR_PARTIAL, VV_RO),
+  VV(VV_CANCEL_EVENT,     "cancel_event",     VAR_BOOL, 0),

comment_data.body:
I don't think I can do that... apply autocmds already returns a bool for if something ran.
wouldn't that conflict?
in the case of QuitPre what that would translate to as I understand it, is if there wasn't any autocmds a window wouldn't close
sure, my suggestion was just to present the concept. Implementation will be non-trivial.

comment_regular_data.body:
known issues
* using `vim.v.event.abort_close = true` doesn't seem to work
* an autocmd that is run after `v:event.abort_close` is set to `true` are able to set it back to `false`

`v:event` should be immutable. Not in favor of special-cases there.

Being able to cancel events (something like `eventcancel(v:event)`) is probably useful but it needs to include good visibility: like how `:verbose set foo?` shows what code modified an option, we need traceability so that plugin authors don't go insane. Logging at `INFO` level would be the minimum.

> My use case for this is an autocmd that pre-quit checks if the alternate buffer is a terminal (i.e. after a `git commit` invokes `nvr --remote-wait`) and instead of closing the window swaps back to the terminal buffer.

But the script that performs the quit can just skip the "quit" step.

`CmdlineLeave` also has one mutable `v:event` key, and other keys are immutable:
```
							*CmdlineLeave*
CmdlineLeave			Before leaving the command-line (including
				non-interactive use of ":" in a mapping: use
				|<Cmd>| instead to avoid this).
				<afile> expands to the |cmdline-char|.
				Sets these |v:event| keys:
				    abort (mutable)
				    cmdlevel
				    cmdtype
				Note: `abort` can only be changed from false
				to true: cannot execute an already aborted
				cmdline by changing it to false.
```

> v:event should be immutable. Not in favor of special-cases there.

This is pretty much correct, after taking another look I found that `FileChangedShell` has v:fcs_choice which gets checks after the autocmd is preformed.

 so I think a feature like this should use something like `v:abort_win_close` or  `v:cancel_window_closure` instead
 
 > it needs to include good visibility: like how :verbose set foo? shows what code modified an option

I can't really think of a way that would work..

> `CmdlineLeave` also has one mutable `v:event` key, and other keys are immutable:

Because Bram designed that API. Very unfortunate

> so I think a feature like this should use something like `v:abort_win_close` or `v:cancel_window_closure` instead

`v:fcs_choice` is an ancient API and should not be used as a precedent. 

Why would we need special-case `v:` variables to cancel an event? Why wouldn't we name it either `v:event_cancel` or `eventcancel()` ?


> I can't really think of a way that would work..

It doesn't need to work exactly like `:verbose`. I mentioned logging.

Someone on matrix recommended I try and send a PR to vim first so I plan on doing that first

> But the script that performs the quit can just skip the "quit" step.

the idea would be after you open something using `--remote` you'd be able to just `:q` and return to the terminal you were working in... I'm not really familiar with how `--remote` works but at least for me when using it, it replaces the terminal buffer with the file I opened.

> the idea would be after you open something using `--remote` you'd be able to just `:q` and return to the terminal you were working in... I'm not really familiar with how `--remote` works but at least for me when using it, it replaces the terminal buffer with the file I opened.

sounds more and more like an XY problem.

> sounds more and more like an XY problem.

kind of... though I did explain the exact problem I was trying to solve so not exactly :/

> v:event_cancel

I think this makes a lot more sense.
Closing due to inactivity. Needs a signficant rework / careful thought.

labels.description: Need comments/opinions from people familiar with this topic.
labels.name: needs:discussion

title: feat(QuitPre): allow aborting window closure with v:event.abort_close
